title: Technical feasability
text:
Potential Issue
Back up plan




Technical Issues

API Rate Limits
Changes in API
Large datasets from Smithsonian or Reddit may slow processing and overwhelm storage


Use alternate APIs if one fails: e.g World Bank API, other museum APIs, Twitter api
Keep an eye on the number of requests being made
Use API-provided bulk download options, like Smithsonian’s collections dump.
Download and store datasets locally for continued analysis if APIs become inaccessible.



Data Quality Issues Incomplete Data:

FRED may lack micro-economic context
Reddit content can include spam, irrelevant posts, or off-topic discussions
Data might reflect institutional or user biases


Clean the data to remove any irrelevant content



Analysis

Assigning art themes to economic or social periods is inherently interpretive and may lead to subjective conclusions
Correlations does not mean causation


Clearly state assumptions, limitations, and potential biases in the project’s findings.



Data Privacy: Scraping

Data must comply with ethical guidelines and the API’s terms of service


Review and strictly adhere to API terms of service and usage policies

title: Research Questions
text:
Historically, the countries that have tended to be richer have also made more artworks (e.g Roman and Greek empire)
We wondered whether there was any correlation between the art themes present in a certain country and the economic well being of that country.
We chose America because it is the hub of economic activity and therefore if might be interesting to see if it has a strong correlation between popular art themes.

title: Research Questions
text:
Historically, the countries that have tended to be richer have also made more artworks (e.g Roman and Greek empire)

title: Research Questions
section: 2. How do social movements affect recent art themes in America?
text:
2. How do social movements affect recent art themes in America?

We chose this to get a broader perspective on what affects art themes in America and build on our findings from question 1.
